item.title: Topic 4: Bayesianism
item.description: Bayesianism, as an approach to inductive reasoning, focuses on updating our beliefs in light of new evidence. It is built around a simple formula that expreses a relationship between probabilities. Reading Hacking, Chapter 7 “Bayes’ Rule” (pages 69–77) Hacking, Chapter 13 “Personal Probabilities” (pages 151–160) Hacking, Chapter 21 “Learning from Experience as an Evasion of the Problem of Induction” (4 pages) — and if you’re not feeling sufficiently familiar with “the problem of induction,” look at the first pages of Chapter 20 See also Elliott Sober, “Introduction to Bayesian Epistemology” Hacking, Chapter 14 “Coherence” (pages 163–169)

item.title: Topic 3: Probability
item.description: Here we set up some basic ideas about probability which will be key for understanding the approaches to scientific justification which have dominated the last several decades. Reading Hacking, Introduction to Probability and Inductive Logic Chapter 4 “Elementary Probability Ideas” Chapter 5 “Conditional Probability” Chapter 11 “What Do You Mean?” Slides Probability Probability-2 Note: These are PDFs which you should be able to view easily.

item.title: Topic 2: Early Methods
item.description: As modern science emerged, its practitioners tried to describe how they were reasoning, and how others should reason, to do science. They came to quite different answers! This unit looks quickly at a few landmarks from the period 1600–1900. Reading Francis Bacon, The New Organon (1620). Read Book 2, sections 10–16 (this starts on page 53 of the linked PDF), but skim through the examples to get a general sense of what’s going on with them, and focus on the beginning and end.

item.title: Topic 1: Logic
item.description: What is logic? What is deductive logic? Could deductive logic be the logic of science? Is non-deductive logic possible? Reading (This is what you should read for this section. The due dates appear on the schedule.) Ian Hacking, An Introduction to Probability and Inductive Logic (purchased book) Chapter 1 “Logic”, whole chapter, pages 1–7. Robin Smith, “Aristotle’s Logic” in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Read the brief/unnumbered preface then sections 1, 2, 3, and 6.
